column3: Planning on leaving the files named *win32.yml?\nNeeds rebase.\n
Rebased and renamed.\n

Hm the installer seems to work, but for 64 bit is called:

```
build/out/64/bitcoin-0.8.99-win32-setup.exe
```

This should obviously be win64.

I also wonder whether the 64-bit installler picks the `Program Files` instead of `Program Files (x86)` correctly when installed on a 64-bit system. I suppose not without further work on the installer.

Edit: this looks helpful http://bojan-komaz

Successfully built all deps except qt-win.yml fails with not enough space available within the VM.  Did you use non-defaults in creating a larger VM disk?

./bin/gbuild --commit bitcoin=v${VERSION} ../bitcoin/contrib/gitian-descriptors/qt-win.yml

> - tar xzf /home/ubuntu/build/qt-everywhere-opensource-src-5.2.0.tar.gz
>   tar: qt-everywhere-opensource-src-5.2.0/qtwebkit/Source/WebCore/render
I used the default, I see that the default VM image size changed 10GB in https://github.com/devrandom/gitian-builder/commit/95e09ae608a34f73a292c9df9e2d0e1c238236f9 \n

Ok, the installer should be sane now.

It shows 32/64-bit in the window caption, picks the right program files directory, and errors out when trying to install the 64-bit version on a 32-bit system.
I take it the installer itself is still 32-bit? Might be ideal to make it 64-bit as well, so people can run without WoW64...\n

@luke-jr There is no working 64-bit version of NSIS afaik, and if it exists it's way too recent to be in Ubuntu 12.04. Having a 32-bit installer executable has the added advantage that it's possible to give a sensible error to people running the 64-bit installer on a 32-bit system.\n
I guess non-WoW64 users are rare enough they can just use the ZIP\n

Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/fe14e8d790f05beb6d01bb380fea873cec5de3ba for binaries and test log.\nThis test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/cu
@luke-jr Every x64 Windows has WOW64 layer AFAIK.\n

WOW64 is the x86 emulator that allows 32-bit Windows-based applications to run seamlessly on 64-bit Windows. WOW64 is provided with the operating system and does not have to be explicitly enabled. For more information, seeWOW64 Implementation Detailshttp://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa384274(v=vs.85).aspx.\n\nThe system isolates 32-bit applications from 64-bit applications, w

Right, let's close the WOW64 discussion and go back to testing the pull. Seeing how long Windows kept around support for 16-bit applications, I'm not really worried about 32-bit support being dropped any time soon in the default installs.\n
Well, WoW64 is already optional on at least one OS, but again we still have the installerless ZIP.\n
This shed color is good enough.\n
I wonder if there'd be a better way to just name the architecture, regardless of what it is?\n
Well, this is mostly aimed at windows users, putting a host tuple wouldn't be more enlightening for them.\n
Please add the rm -f ?\n
As it works fine with the default configuration of gitian (which has a 10GB disk), I'd like to keep it like this. It's useful to be able to ssh and inspect the intermediate files in the VM.\n
Maybe x86 / x64, but that is even more confusing?\n

In the installer I use the `(32-bit)`/`(64-bit)` convention, so using the same convention here would make sense.

Sure, we could use x86/x64 but then everything would need to be changed, and I don't see much advantage. People that compile and run Bitcoin on 'other' architectures know what they're doing and don't need to be reminded in the About: dialog.

If this is really a point of contention

The two ARM users might want a version label. =)

Nice addition.
x86_32 and x86_64 would probably be ideal, but let's not shed-paint it... x86/x64 is _definitely_ wrong, though! There is no such thing as x64.\n
